statement:
Let $f(z)$ be an entire function such that $\vert f(z)\vert \leq K
e^{\gamma \vert z\vert}$ for some $K \geq 0$ and $\gamma > 0$. If the
restriction of $f$ to the real line is in $L^2(\mathbb{R})$, then there
exists a function $g(t)\in L^2(-\gamma, \gamma)$ such that
$$f(z) = \frac{1}{\sqrt{2\pi}}\int_{-\gamma}^{\gamma}g(t)e^{izt}dt$$ for
all $z$.
